Reference an existing “between” alignment space that you have already setup.
Associate a reference autolayout’s query to which all frame calculations
will be based on. If there is more than one item returned
from the reference query AND those items are siblings,
an alignment layer will be used that is the
of all
items returned, such that any frame calculations made will
be relative to the union of those items.
NOTE: For union references (based on multiple items), the
query’s
item must be the literal parent of the query items,
in order for the alignment to occur relative to it’s coordinate space.
If more than one union reference is used within a given parent
(e.g. reference based on diverse items) pass a unique “alignment id” to
ensure there is no conflict with alignment layers.
TIP: As with all reference operators, to re-parent the item(s)
to the reference, follow this call with attachToReference().
Reference this view’s (or in the case of multiple views,
common parent view’s) safe area layout guide to which all
subsequent frame calculations will be based on.
Remember that the safe area guide on the view is the
intersection of the safe area of the window and the view’s
bounds, which means if you need to pin all edges you can
do so in one operation. Remember too, that in the context
of a view controller you may use
which will be added to the safe area.
Reference an existing alignment layer that you have already setup.
Associate a reference item to which all frame calculations
will be based on. Specify the item type and tag.
This method performs a query from the current query’s base and
assigns the first item found (of type and tag) to the
query’s reference.
Example: query.reference(CircleView.self, tag:Tags.foo).mutate
TIP: As with all reference operators, to re-parent the item(s)
to the reference, follow this call with attachToReference().
Supports multiple item references (union) – if items are siblings.
To reference multiple items of the same type/tag provide
value which can be an integer of the number of items to be found
or if that value is not known, nil. (For performance prefer
explicitly providing integer value.)
To debug the hierarchy used for the reference search precede
this call with

will be relative to parent (as normal).
Associate a reference query derived from the current query
to which all frame calculations will be based on.
(This variation is “derived” in the sense that you can go from the
current query via “with” operator or other export operators to further
query the hierarchy using the current query’s items as the base.)

Associate a quadrant guide (e.g. “A1:B2”) within a grid
(that is the ancestor/previous from the current query)
to which all frame calculations of the item(s) will be based.
SIDE-EFFECT: If the quadrant does not already exist in the
grid it will be created/attached.
This supports multiple items referencing a single quadrant.
TIP: As with all reference operators, to re-parent the item(s)
to the referenced quadrant, follow this call with attachToReference().
